issue.title: Stuck Workers

repository.name: sidekiq
repository.description: Simple, efficient background processing for Ruby

issue.body:
Hello everyone.

I've been dealing with a problem which my some of my workers get stuck, and I can't backtrace why. Check the attachments.

I've been trying to use kill -TTIN #{worker_pid} but I don't know how to find out the worker pid which is stuck, and the best way (I guess) to do that is make automatically, without having to log into the remote server and checking out which worker is stuck, then killing it.

I guess a solution for that would be a cron to check this out.
Can you give me any insights on from where should I start?

![screen shot 2014-02-20 at 10 50 18 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1319459/2225191/fe98376a-9a88-11e3-85e1-cb80e1e9f428.png)

![screen shot 2014-02-20 at 11 00 40 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1319459/2225192/011442ae-9a89-11e3-88d1-80b85d920133.png)

Thanks!

issue.title: Process not terminating on segfault

repository.name: sidekiq
repository.description: Simple, efficient background processing for Ruby

issue.body:
We recently updated sidekiq from 2.12.4 to 2.17.4 and everything worked fine - until we noticed that when a worker segfaults, the sidekiq process keeps hanging. TTIN shows only a single line (such as "Thread TID-7gru0").
Although we're going to fix the segfault (caused by nokogiri, in this case) it'd be relieving to know that sidekiq crashes thoroughly on segfaults so that it can be restarted (by god, in this case).
We're on ruby-1.9.3-p194. The problem did not occur on sidekiq 2.12.4.

Anything else I can help with?

Thanks a lot in advance - and for the great work you're investing in this project! =)

issue.title: busy queue not clearing

repository.name: sidekiq
repository.description: Simple, efficient background processing for Ruby

issue.body: I'm regularly seeing a small percentage of workers in the busy queue that never seem to disappear.  Does this mean that these jobs never processed?  If I clear the workers list am I'm a preventing these jobs from retrying?

body: Nice to see that change! In addition to being confusing, a long list like ours (can accumulate >20k entries) and polling it appears in Redis' slow log regularly, causing short Redis timeouts of other driver connections (using redis-rb on hiredis).

issue.title: Limits not limiting

repository.name: sidekiq-limit_fetch
repository.description: A Sidekiq plugin to support advanced queue control (limiting, pausing, blocking, querying)

issue.body:
It seems queues just aren't being limited. Here's my `sidekiq.yml` file:

```
:concurrency: 81
:queues:
  - [fast, 10]
  - [default, 3]
  - [slow, 1]
  - [a, 5]
  - [b, 5]
  - [c, 5]
  - [d, 5]
:limits:
  slow: 45
  fast: 10
  default: 20
  a: 2
  b: 2
  c: 2
  d: 2
```

And this is how I'm running sidekiq on Heroku (from my Procfile):
`worker: env DB_POOL=100 bundle exec sidekiq -e $RACK_ENV -C config/sidekiq.yml`

Looking in Sidekiq's list of Busy workers, queue `b` has 8 workers...even though it's limited to 2.

I have 3 2X workers in Heroku.

Any ideas?

Sidekiq 2.17.6
sidekiq-limit_fetch 2.1.3

body: I have jobs who take more than 1 hour, how see them ?
@sb4m You'll need to upgrade to Sidekiq 3.0, which is the master branch.  It's not be released as a gem yet.

issue.title: Clarify README about unique expiration
issue.body:
I wanted to make sure I understood how long the uniqueness of a job lasts and, if my observation is correct, update the README accordingly. 

I'm confident that the job will be unique for the shorter of the seconds configured or seconds for the job to complete. See: https://github.com/mhenrixon/sidekiq-unique-jobs/blob/master/lib/sidekiq-unique-jobs/middleware/client/unique_jobs.rb#L47

I'm less confident about my observation with Sidekiq versions before 3.0, but I'm pretty sure it's the reason why my long running jobs do not remain unique. See: https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq/issues/1508#issuecomment-37523281 and https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq/blob/20b7a4fe47585ce9c43981305d146bd087540bbf/lib/sidekiq/web_helpers.rb#L50-L83

Thanks!
